title: Finding the Central Idea
learning_objectives: Identify the central idea or main claim of a passage
Distinguish central ideas from supporting details
Use evidence to justify answer choices
Avoid common traps (too broad, too narrow, or outside the text)

content.title: Central Ideas & Evidence
content.subtitle: Big-picture understanding
points: Recognize the author‚Äôs main claim or purpose
Select evidence that directly supports the main claim

content.title: Classic Traps
content.explanation: Answers look appealing because they lift words from the passage but distort scope or focus on a minor detail.
content.example: If the passage argues renewable energy is *promising but challenging*, a trap might claim it 'solves all climate problems' ‚Äî too broad.

content.title: 4-Step Process
steps: Step 1: Ask after each paragraph ‚Äî 'Why is the author telling me this?'
Step 2: Predict the main idea in 5‚Äì7 words before answer choices.
Step 3: Eliminate answers that exaggerate or miss the scope.
Step 4: Confirm the correct answer is supported in at least 2 places.

content.title: Apply the Strategy
content.question: The passage primarily argues that:
choices: Technological innovation alone can fully solve food shortages.
A combination of innovation and traditional farming practices offers the most promise.
Traditional farming should be abandoned in favor of modern techniques.
Food shortages are unavoidable due to climate change.
content.explanation: Only B captures the balanced claim. A is too absolute, C is too extreme, D is out of scope.

content.title: Solution Walkthrough
solution_steps: Passage shows success = blend of old + new.

content.title: Mastering Central Ideas
content.summary: Central idea Qs = big picture, not details.
key_points: Beware traps: broad, narrow, outside text.
Confirm with multiple pieces of evidence.
content.next_steps: Practice with paired passages for mastery.
